item.title: Fostering a Healthier Relationship with Digital Media Consumption and the Ever-Present Smartphone
item.description:
The Trouble with Time

I spend a lot of time on my phone.

Big shocker, I know; me and nearly everyone else.

However, if you were to ask me how much time I spend on my phone each day on average, I don't think I'd be able to give you even an approximation. Somewhere between 1 and 5 hours?

With the addition of the Screen Time in iOS, I now have access to a report of exactly how much time I spend on my phone, with that time broken apart on a per-app basis. Screen Time has been in iOS for a while, but I've never really bothered to check it or to configure any time limits on apps. Maybe I'm scared of quantifying the time I've spent on my phone, especially on apps for services such as Reddit, Twitter and Discord.

Honestly though, that's all just a big sunk cost fallacy. It doesn't really matter how much time I have spent historically on my phone, because that's time that has already been spent.

What does matter is being more intentional with how I'm spending my time, and spending less time on my phone if that's not where I want to be spending said time.

Forgive me for being morbid, but a big value in my life is the following statement: Time is a limited resource of which I do not know the quantity. Eventually I will run out of time, and I do not know when that will be. Therefore, I want to be as intentional as possible in how I spend my time; the ultimate goal of this is to live what I consider to be a fulfilling and meaningful life.

What do I want to do with my time, and why?

I've identified that I'm spending what I feel to be "too much" time on pursuits I view to not be worth the time spent; this is mostly excess time on my phone, which we'll analyze further in a bit.

What pursuits or activities are "worth the time"? This is a difficult question to answer (at least for me it is), and the answer to this question is entirely subjective.

I could identify the set of activities that I deem worthy of my time, and schedule out all available time in my calendar to ensure I'm consistently spending time on worthwhile things.

However, following a schedule of what I had deduced to be the optimal "life"…that doesn't sound like the life I want to live. Additionally, what I view to be important to me will certainly change over time, especially after major life events.

As a result, I feel that identifying what my core values are is a better way to approach this exercise. Whenever I go to engage in an activity, I can briefly reflect on whether that activity is aligned or otherwise contributes to my values, and thus proceed accordingly.

While my values may mutate over time, they are core principles to me and should remain fairly static.

Values

Loved Ones

Sartre's Hell may be "other people", but I want my paradise to be spending time with my loved ones.

Honestly, I have been distracted away from this value to the point where writing the previous statement felt dishonest; it's critical to my longterm happiness that I make time with my loved ones my top priority.

Activities that embody this value:

  • Spending "active" time with friends/family, whether in person or over a video call.

Continuous Self-Improvement

I love to learn new things and commit to pursuits that demonstrate measurable self improvement to a fault; I am especially susceptible to skill intensive games. I will throw myself deeply into a new game, spend hours upon hours learning as much as I can…only to get distracted by and commit to a new game.

I recognize that I have this drive for self improvement, as misplaced as it often can be.

Ideally, I want to commit to pursuits where I am learning or growing as a person; results of these pursuits ideally benefit my personal or professional life.

Activities that embody this value:

  • Exercise

  • Reading (Non-Fiction)

  • Programming

  • Language Learning (Chinese)

Foster Creativity and Create

Similar to the value of Continuous Self-Improvement, I want to ensure that I'm fostering my own creativity and creating things.

When I was a teenager, I was very much into poetry - it helped me to express myself in areas where I felt uncomfortable confiding in others. I haven't written poetry in quite a while, and while I wouldn't restrict myself from picking that back up one day, I think it's more important that I foster my general creativity.

These days I tend to express myself more through coding, and while that doesn't express my emotions to the same extent that poetry does, it's a pursuit that allows me to create something from an idea and thus gives me a sense of satisfaction. I also express myself and introspect by way of this blog; any pursuits that influence me to keep writing are ones that I would consider valuable.

On this front, consuming content created by others (especially digital content) can be a way of fostering my own creativity. I am not restricting myself from this, but this is approaching the area where careful balance is required; I must very intentionally choose the movies, tv shows, online videos, podcasts, etc. that I wish to consume.

Activities that embody this value:

  • Reading (Fiction, Non-Fiction, Blogs, etc.)

  • Programming

  • Consuming Intentionally Chosen Digital Media (Movies, TV Shows, Podcasts, Games, etc.)

Content Troughs and "Infinite" Media

Forgive me for the introspection of the previous section; while valuable for crafting my own guiding light, we have diverged a bit from the original intent of this post.

Reflecting on my values before engaging in an activity and proceeding accordingly is great and all, but I don't believe that this solves the original issue of spending too much time on my phone.

Pulling my phone out of my pocket is a physical habit - I have years of muscle memory built up of reaching for the device whenever I am not actively engaged in an activity. Even worse is when I pull out my phone when I am engaged in an activity such as programming or talking to someone. At best this is a distraction, at worst it's downright disrespectful.

Even over the course of the days where I have been working on this blog post, with the intent to reduce my phone time on my mind, I still find myself scrolling ad nauseam. When I wake up, the first thing I do is reach for my phone and find myself scrolling through Twitter, Instagram, Reddit and Discord before I even wake up fully. Sometimes I'll stay in the bed for a full 30 extra minutes before getting started with my day; I could be having a coffee and enjoying the cool morning breeze out on the roof instead!

I can feel myself driven by a sense of FOMO, or "Fear Of Missing Out"; a sense of wanting to catch up on everything that might have happened while I was asleep drives me to spend this time each morning.

The content that instills this feeling is what I'm going to describe as a content trough. I do not use this term to liken all the content to that of livestock feed - much of this content is entertaining and worthwhile. Some content creators put a lot of hard work into their content creation and I greatly respect their efforts.

Content troughs are carefully designed to keep you looking at it; this makes sense, they often make more profit the longer they keep you looking. They do this by using algorithms that determine what to show you next based on your previous viewing habits. These algorithms are pretty damn good at knowing what to show you to keep you scrolling and/or watching.

I am not writing this to denounce the creators of these content trough algorithms for their malice nor to try to incite rebellion against them. I am writing this to acknowledge the following fact: I am very susceptible to suggested content algorithms or sources of nigh-infinite media, and to live what I feel would be a more meaningful life, I'm choosing to limit my exposure to them.

While these content troughs are available on both my desktop computer as well as my phone, I find myself generally more resistant on the computer. Regardless, during times when I am trying to be productive or otherwise ensure I spend my time wisely, I have an extension in my browser that allows me to arbitrarily block and unblock sites.

Since I consider the phone to be the contributing factor of my poorly spent time, I will focus on that for the remainder of this post.

So what am I going to do about this phone problem?

As romantic as the idea of reflecting on my values prior to getting distracted on my phone sounds, I know that whipping out my phone and getting sucked into the content within is a habit that must be broken. Currently, the allure and convenience of the phone is too strong. Breaking the habit and making pulling out my phone feel more foreign (similar to how ex-smokers find holding a cigarette to be an odd feeling) will make it easier for me to be more intentional with how I choose to spend those moments.

1. Phone Stays Out of Reach While At Home

The biggest issue of the phone feels like the convenience - it's in my pocket and thus available at a moment's notice.

Thus my first action is to keep the phone on its charging pad in the bedroom while I'm at home instead of keeping it in my pocket or next to me on my desk.

I do not regularly hang out in or pass through the bedroom during the day unless I'm doing chores; this location should be inconveient enough to prevent me from absent mindedly retrieving it.

2. Aggressive Content Trough Restrictions

Ideally, I want a moment of reflection prior to being able to access a content trough where I can briefly stop myself to ask, "Is this what I want to do right at this moment?".

To achieve this pre-content moment, I am implementing an aggressive usage of Screen Time: an explicit app allow-list via Screen Time, and web content restrictions on sites I absent mindedly access in the browser rather than via an app.

For the curious, here's how I achieved this (note for extra clarity: iOS specific):

  1. Settings -> Screen Time -> Downtime Enabled -> Every Day; From 12:00AM; To 11:59PM;

  2. Settings -> Screen Time -> Always Allowed -> Add all apps you believe should not be restricted.

    • Apps I kept Never Allowed: comiXology, Discord, Instagram, Pokemon Go, Twitch, Twitter, YouTube. In this process I also deleted the Facebook and LinkedIn app after struggling to find a reason I would need them on my phone.

    • Yes, the explicit allow list must be updated whenever you add a new application; this is a fairly uncommon occurence for me, so find the pros outweigh the cons.

  3. Settings -> Screen Time -> Content & Privacy Restrictions Enabled -> Content Restrictions -> Web Content -> Limit Adult Websites -> Never Allow -> Add all sites you want to restrict on your phone.

    • I only ended up restricting Reddit, as this is effectively the only site I will absent mindedly go to and start scrolling on. However, according to Screen Time this is the content trough where I am overwhelmingly spending excess time (up to 3 hours a day).

    • Unlike the other Screen Time settings, it is very difficult to allow one-time access. If you click the "Allow Website" button when visiting a blocked page, it removes it from the "Never Allow" list and places it on the "Always Allow" list. Thus I recommend only adding sites that you never want to visit on your mobile browser to this list.

One might ask at this point why I did not just delete the content trough apps rather than restricting them? The reason is that I don't want to make these apps completely inaccessible - each has their time and place, and I value the content and enjoyment they can bring to my life.

My main goal is truly to afford myself a moment of reflecting to choose to do something different if I so desire. The content troughs are just so damn convenient, I just need to make them a little less in order to make the correct decision more often.

In Summary

This post details actions that are in process - I am still determining if the described settings enact the change in my life I desire with regards to reducing my phone usage.

Assuming all goes well, I will write a follow up of how reducing my phone usage and focusing on pursuits that align with my values have improved my mental health and quality of life. One might summarize this as living a more meaningful and intentional life, which is something that I certainly want to strive to do.

Thank you for reading my self-improvement stream of consciousness, I hope that my internal reflecting might inspire you to do the same, or to re-evaluate how you interact with your phone. <

item.title: Speedrunning: A Dance of Dependencies and Restrictions
item.description:
Thesis

What does it mean to complete a "speedrun" of a video game? Abstractly, completing a "speedrun" of a game is to satisfy some predetermined set of dependencies as quickly as possible while adhering to a predetermined set of restrictions.

This post will explore the nature of these sets of "dependencies" and "restrictions" that the community establishes for their games.

The Definition of Completion can be Subjective

Let's take a step back: what does it mean to beat a game?

This is subjective, but an attempted casual answer to this question might look like this: "Progress through the game's story, complete all the levels, and defeat the final boss."

The game presents challenges to the player, and when the player completes these challenges they emerge triumphant: they have "beaten" the game. The credits roll, a virtual world is saved (maybe) and they are left with a sense of accomplishment.

However, the player could reload their save file and explore all remaining nooks and crannies in the game - maybe the game even has a meter that display a completion percentage, and the player could continue until that displays 100%. This is another form of completion that one might call full completion.

In the speedrunning world, each game's community will typically define at what point the game is considered beaten or completed. Throughout the rest of this post, this community defined point will be referred to as the definition of completion, or DoC for brevity.

Let's consider two examples where our DoC is to defeat the game's final boss:

  • What if the game this game was non-linear, and didn't require the player to visit all areas of the game and "consume" all of the content within prior to confronting the final boss? The player would probably try to visit every required area as quickly as possible, gather all required items/skills, and confront the final boss as early as is possible.

  • Now, what if the game was linear, but the player learned of a way to bypass an area that was intended to be required, and end up confronting the final boss earlier than would have otherwise been possible? In essence, the only difference between this and the previous example is that the number of areas the player is required to visit is reduced by one. However, how the player is playing the game is now inherently different. They are no longer playing by the game's rules - they are executing an action that the developers (probably) did not intend for the player to do.

Dependencies

Let's abstract this concept of required "things" the player has to do to beat the game to be a dependency.

A dependency is something that the player must satisfy in order to achieve their DoC. Examples of common dependencies one finds in games are completing a level, collecting an item, and reading specific character dialogues.

To satisfy the definition of beating the game in the lowest amount of time possible, the player has two key ways of saving time:

  1. Improving their own gameplay and consistency through practice

  2. Finding ways of reducing dependencies so that they have overall less game to play.

There is a certain irony in the fact that the most passionate fans of a game spend countless hours discovering and applying new ways of reducing the amount of the game they have to play.

As time passes…

The longer a game sticks around, the more things players will discover that allow them to reduce dependencies. Players find ways of tricking the game into warping the player to late in the game or giving the player key items outside of the expected source.

Eventually, a game may reach a state with some of the following issues:

  • The number of dependencies to beat the game may be a fraction of what it used to be - multi-hour games may be reduced to an hour or two (or in our upcoming case study, less than 10 minutes).

  • The techniques discovered that allow players to bypass large segments of the game may be technically very difficult, or inconsistent leading to them being "not fun".

  • The player population may have pushed their skill level to such a point that, barring the discovery of new ways to reduce dependencies even further, faster times become very unlikely barring absolute perfection of gameplay.

To keep the game fresh and fun, community members may experiment with applying limitations on themselves to reduce the available actions they can perform to bypass dependencies. Doing so changes how the player must play the game, as the fastest sequence of actions they could take to satisfy the DoC will depend on what options are available to them.

Thus enters the concept of restrictions.

Restrictions

A restriction is something that the player is not allowed to do in their pursuit of satisfying the DoC.

Restrictions are often placed in order to modify the route (ordered sequence of actions) that the player takes to satisfy the DoC as quickly as possible.

Alternatively, restrictions may be put into place to ensure fairness across the player base. For example, if a version of the game that had a very limited print run (and is thus expensive to acquire second hand) is shown to be substantially faster due to a version exclusive trick, the community may opt to ban this trick to keep the fastest times from being cost prohibitive.

Theoretical Example of Applying Restrictions and/or Dependencies for Route Variety

Here's a theoretical example: there exists a game where one must go collect three magic flowers from dungeons in order to open a door immediately behind which lies the final boss fight. The community defines the DoC as "Defeating the final boss."

The boss door is located very near to where the player begins the game. It is discovered over time that there is a load trigger (some portion of 3D space that, when touched by the player character, will load a different portion of the game and teleport the character there) that is always loaded behind the door. If the player were able to make their character touch this load trigger, they would enter the boss fight regardless of how many magic flower they have collected. Naturally, a technique is eventually discovered that allows players to consistently touch the load trigger without opening the door by exploiting a glitch to clip (i.e. pass through something solid) through the door. With this technique in hand, players now have the ability to confront the final boss almost instantly after starting a new game; this bypasses almost the entirety of the game's content.

While this door clip may enable the fastest known way to defeat the final boss, this may not be the experience that the player wants to do over and over while they work on improving their time. In this case, some players may choose to apply a restriction of disallowing glitches that allow clipping. Adhering to this restriction would form a new route, as the player would once again be forced to go collect the three magic flowers in order to open the door via the "intended" means.

Alternatively, players might consider the glitch that enables the clip not to be the part of the route they take issue with; maybe the glitch is fun to execute or opens up possibilities in how to approach obstacles in the game. In this case, players might instead opt to include an additional dependency in their DoC, such that it reads as "Collect all three magic flowers then defeat the final boss."

The difference between disallowing the clip glitch altogether rather than requiring the player collect all the magic flowers is that, in the latter case, the player is free to utilize the clip glitch to make the collection of the magic flowers a faster endeavor. Even better, if there is a long cutscene that the player would need to watch of their character presenting the flowers to open the boss door, it may be faster for the player to clip past the door after collecting the flowers anyway!

Assuming the route that player takes to satisfy the DoC in either case is entertaining, other players may become interested in running it. This creates the need for a named grouping of dependencies and/or restrictions.

Categories

A speedrun category for a game is a named grouping of dependencies and/or restrictions. Dependencies will often be abstracted as a high level DoC (e.g. "Collect all three magic flowers then defeat the final boss"), whereas the restrictions will often be a list of banned techniques or categories of techniques.

Case Study - Zelda: Ocarina of Time

All information in this case study is current as of August 23rd, 2020. It will eventually become outdated thanks to the beautiful dynamism of speedrunning.

The Intended Path

Considering an "intended" DoC of "Defeat the final boss.", the following details a very high level overview of the actions (without the story context) the player is meant to take in order to satisfy the DoC. Navi, the player's fairy companion, will periodically hint the player of where they should go next and takes them on this path. If you've played Zelda: Ocarina of Time before, you can probably skip this section.

  1. Collect Sword and Shield in Kokiri Forest, beat Deku Tree, collect Kokiri Emerald.

  2. Get Zelda's Letter and Zelda's Lullaby, go up Death Mountain to Goron City. Go back into Kokiri Forest to learn Saria's Song, play it to Darunia to get Goron Bracelet.

  3. Use Goron Bracelet to throw Bomb Flower to open Dodongo's Cavern. Beat Dodongo's Cavern, collect Goron Ruby.

  4. Go up Zora's River to Zora's Domain, win Silver Scale from Diving Game. Dive to Ruto's Letter in Lake Hylia, present to King Zora (mweep).

  5. Present fish to Jabu Jabu, enter belly. Beat Jabu Jabu's Belly, collect Zora Sapphire.

  6. Go back to Hyrule Castle, get Ocarina of Time from Zelda fleeing the castle on horseback.

  7. Open Door of Time using Ocarina of Time + Spiritual Stones, pull Master Sword, become adult. Collect Light Medallion.

  8. Go to Kakariko graveyard, get Hookshot and Song of Storms.

  9. Use Hookshot to enter Forest Temple, beat Forest Temple, get Forest Medallion.

  10. Stop rolling Goron in Goron City to open doors and get Goron Tunic.

  11. Hookshot over bridge to access Fire Temple entrance. Beat Fire Temple, get Fire Medallion.

  12. Go to Ice Cavern in Zora's Fountain, get to the end to collect Iron Boots.

  13. Use Iron Boots and Hookshot to enter Water Temple. Beat Water Temple, get Water Medallion.

  14. Go back to child, get Din's Fire. Use Song of Storms to drain Well in Kakariko, collect Lens of Truth from Bottom of the Well. Go back to adult.

  15. Use Din's Fire to enter Shadow Temple. Beat Shadow Temple, get Shadow Medallion.

  16. Enter Gerudo Fortress, free four carpenters to get the Gerudo Card. Open gate to Haunted Wasteland.

  17. Use Lens to cross Haunted Wasteland. Enter Spirit Temple, realize you can't do anything, leave to collect Requiem of Spirit.

  18. Go back to child, play Requiem of Spirit. Proceed through Spirit Temple until Silver Gauntlets collected.

  19. Go back to adult, play Requiem of Spirit, beat Spirit Temple. Get Spirit Medallion.

  20. Go to Ganon's Castle, cross bridge that appears upon having all six Medallions.

  21. Complete the six trials in Ganon's Castle to dispel the barrier blocking the way to Ganon's Tower.

  22. Climb Ganon's Tower, defeat Ganondorf. Escape as castle collapses.

  23. Investigate strange noise in rubble to initiate Ganon fight. Defeat Ganon, stab it in the face, game beaten.

Category Analyses

Not all categories will be summarized here, only ones that showcase variety in combinations of dependencies and/or restrictions.

The core DoC for OoT is as follows:

  • If defeating Ganon, time ends on the first frame of the final blow cutscene.

  • If wrong warping into the credits, timing ends on the first frame of the fade-in of any cutscene which normally takes place after the Ganon final slash, and which will eventually reach The End screen.

All additional dependencies added into categories are listed separately and are considered required in addition to either of the above.

Many categories have been split into SRM and No SRM variants after the discovery of this glitch, due to the fundamentally route changing nature of it. The variant being analyzed will be noted.

Any%

Summary

Player manipulates in game memory to perform an exploit known as ACE (Arbitrary Code Execution), allowing them to warp to end credits from Kokiri Forest.

Satisfies the wrong warp DoC.

Record as of 8/23/2020: 7m 32s 833ms by Savestate

Dependencies

N/A, WW DoC

Restrictions

N/A

Notable Techniques

  • ACE

100% (SRM)

Summary

Player must achieve 100% completion in the game before defeating Ganon.

Utilizes a huge range of different techniques - the fastest route is nothing remotely close to the intended path through the game.

Record as of 8/23/2020: 3h 38m 01s by zfg

Dependencies

Requirements for 100% completion

Restrictions

  • ACE is banned.

Notable Techniques

Leverages just about every known useful glitch (barring ACE) in Ocarina of Time to go faster, but makes extensive use of SRM.

Defeat Ganon (No SRM)

Summary

Players must complete the "Defeat Ganon" core DoC with only minimal restrictions.

Record as of 8/23/2020: 16m 49s 366ms by RichardSage

Dependencies

N/A, Defeat Ganon DoC

Restrictions

  • SRM and ACE are banned.

Notable Techniques

  • GIM to get bottle in Deku Tree.

  • Ganondoor to wrong warp to collapse sequence

  • HESS off falling rock to skip majority of collapse.

  • ISG with Deku Stick to damage Ganon.

GSR (Ganondorf Source Requirements)

Summary

Players must satisfy the core "Defeat Ganon" DoC after collecting the required items from source necessary to defeat Ganondorf prior to initiating the final fight.

Light Arrows are required to stun Ganondorf in the fight. Light Arrows are acquired from a cutscene that should require owning all medallions - however, the game only checks for the Shadow and Spirit medallions, so those are the only ones required.

Magic is required to shoot Light Arrows. Magic is acquired by playing Zelda's Lullaby at the fairy fountain at the top of Death Mountain.

A quiver is also required to shoot Light Arrows. The quiver is acquired by collecting the Fairy Bow from Forest Temple.

All forms of wrong warping, item manipulation and cut scene skips are disallowed.

Record as of 8/23/2020: 1h 13m 31s by CountLG

Dependencies

Defeat Ganon DoC with following additional dependencies:

  • Defeat Ganondorf

  • Get Light Arrows

    • Collect Shadow and Spirit Medallions

  • Get magic

    • Get Zelda's Lullaby

  • Get Quiver 30

Restrictions

  • Wrong Warping is banned.

  • RBA / BA / GIM are banned.

  • SRM and ACE are banned.

  • Cutscene skips from blue warps banned.

Notable Techniques

  • WESS Escape, Pokey Escape or Walking-While-Talking to leave Kokiri Forest without beating Deku Tree.

  • Cucco or Navi dive to get to Bottom of the Well without draining the water.

  • Blank A or Ocarina Dive to get to Bombchu chest in Bottom of the Well.

  • Damage boosting to get over Hyrule Castle Moat.

  • Dying on same frame as cutscene starting to get Zelda's Lullaby without watching cutscene.

  • DoT skip to bypass all requirements of opening Door of Time.

  • Hookshot jump to enter Shadow Temple early.

  • Boat(key) skip to go directly to Bongo Bongo fight.

  • Damage Clip to bypass Gerudo Gate.

  • Spirit Hover up to Mirror Shield to bypass normal Spirit Temple progression.

  • Statue Climb + Ground Clip or Head Skip to bypass Spirit Temple boss key.

  • Hover Boost to courtyard ledge in Forest Temple.

  • Ground Jumps + Impossible Jump to bypass strength requirement to move blocks in Forest Temple.

  • Trials Skip to bypass doing any trials in Ganon's Castle.

  • Collapse Skip to bypass majority of escape sequence after Ganondorf.

  • Superslide into Ganon fight trigger to keep Master Sword.

Glitchless (Any% Restricted)

Summary

Players must satisfy the normal "Defeat Ganon" DoC while adhering to a comprehensive set of restrictions on allowed techniques.

The category is defined by movement optimizations rather than big "make or break the run" tricks.

Record as of 8/23/2020: 3h 40m 36s by ChefBear

Dependencies

N/A, Defeat Ganon DoC

Restrictions

Please see the official category rules for the full detailed list of allowed and disallowed techniques.

Notable Techniques

Many unique movement optimizations and "parkour" jumps that are unique to the category.

Further Reading/Viewing

Fig's overview of SRM, ACE and beyond

dannyB's overview of the evolution of the Glitchless category

Gymnast86's "Elusive Glitches" video series

The Legend of the Barrier Skip - The Holy Grail of Zelda {Wind Waker} speedrunning

item.title: My Ongoing Journey with Emacs
item.description:
init

I’m rapidly becoming known as “that Emacs guy” in my office.

I’m very vocal about my love for this ~35 year old piece of software, and (unsuccessfully) evangelize it amongst my peers.

Whenever one of my coworkers shows the smallest amount of interest in it, such as “Hey that presentation you gave with the code blocks, what was that in?”, it’s off to the races. I’m prone to inundate them with additional reading materials and youtube videos about emacs and org-mode and why they should also consider using it to organize their life.

Naturally, I’m rarely asked about it twice.

I still consider myself to be very junior as an Emacs user. There’s much I do not know, and even more that I do not know that I do not know.

As of this writing, I’ve been casually interested in Emacs for about two years, and have been a fervent user with it as my primary IDE and organization tool for the past six-eight months.

With this post, I’m hoping to detail out my ever ongoing journey as an Emacs user. I’m hoping that this will prove to be useful to newcomers to Emacs, or that it will at least expand my currently very small social network of Emacs users.

history

the dark ages

Let’s get one thing out of the way - while pursuing my computer science degree in college, I was mostly a Vim user.

I wasn’t really a power user, but I could navigate effectively. My Vim config was mostly copied from others on the internet, but without understanding what everything did. Once I graduated college and took a non-coding job, I didn’t really have much text editing work to do, and I dropped off Vim.

Vim is still my go-to when remoting into servers and making quick changes, which honestly is the perfect use case for it.

pursuing enlightenment

Emacs has been on my radar ever since I started getting into programming, but my first attempt at using it was probably in 2015. I was working as a technician at an IT helpdesk, so I wasn’t very opinionated about my text editors yet. A friend of mine was working at a startup doing Android work, and his boss at the time used Emacs keybindings in IntelliJ. Apparently whenever his boss came over and wanted to type something, he would fail due to the built in IntelliJ bindings, so he “strongly encouraged” my friend to switch.

After hearing about the interesting keybindings, I thought I’d go straight to the source: I downloaded Emacs to see what it was all about.

I probably lasted less than 5 minutes. It seemed so old school! The splash screen was ugly, I didn’t know what all the UI elements were, and I struggled through the built in tutorial.

I promptly uninstalled Emacs, and moved on with my life, proclaiming that it wasn’t for me.

I switched jobs to an Ad Tech company doing Tier 1.5 work (vendor certification work), and during this time I mostly used Notepad++ for jamming down random notes. I never saved any of them, so I probably ended that job with 300 tabs in NP++ memory.

reattempting enlightenment

In early 2017, I got myself my first real programming job - huzzah! The role was in the IT sector of a bank, and I was working on a platform that exposed APIs for working with in-house infrastructure. This was a greenfield project, and we decided to build it with a container and microservice-first approach. Being a large enterprise financial company, we settled on the JVM as our application runtime, with Java as the core language. Naturally, IntelliJ was the IDE of choice.

It wasn’t long until I discovered Clojure. Clojure is a functional programming language - a lisp that runs in the JVM. It’s elegant and production ready. To this day, I’ve not had the opportunity to work with Clojure much, but I’ve always been in love with its principles.

I decided I wanted to learn Clojure, and to try to integrate it into our API platform - if all our microservices were JVM based, who says one couldn’t be in Clojure?

I borrowed the book Clojure for the Brave and True from my team lead at the time, who also had pipe dreams of using Clojure for a financial modeling startup. Brave Clojure (as I’ll call it henceforth) is a great book - it has hearty doses of humor, and is a must read if you’re interested in Clojure. At the end of the first chapter, the book describes a few different popular IDE options for Clojure - namely, Emacs as well as IntelliJ with the Cursive plugin. However, the author is moderatly opinionated, and the second chapter of the book is entirely about configuring and using Emacs.

I pored over every word in this Emacs chapter - I found it fascinating. It was describing a way to configure and use Emacs to achieve a productive programming workflow. This is what was lacking on my first Emacs attempt, I had no goal - I tried using Emacs for the sake of using it.

This chapter does have one issue though, which is that the author provides a zip file of a recommended Emacs configuration. This configuration has not aged entirely well (there have been a few packages in the last few years which would clean it up, such as use-package), and will not suit all users. Additionally, if it ever breaks, the user will likely be dead in the water on what to do.

Regardless, I used this configuration and followed every step of the chapter. I also gave the built in tutorial another go, to greater success. I was beginning to understand the fluidity of using Emacs, but I still had no knowledge in configuring and tweaking it for my use cases.

I now felt comfortable with Emacs, but pretty much only for Clojure with the Brave Clojure configuration. It felt a bit like having one highly specialized tool in your work belt that you used once a year, if ever. I ended up not having too much spare time to work on Clojure, and as a result my Emacs usage dwindled into nothingness.

What did persist however, were the keybindings. I made the decision to swap my IntelliJ keybindings to be the built in Emacs keymap. It did a pretty good job mapping navigational keys and common operations to their default Emacs values. Quickly, nobody besides me could use my IntelliJ anymore (made more difficult with my keyboard, a HHKB), and I had the muscle memory for navigational keys well developed.

enlightenment as a primary IDE

Fast forward to the beginning of 2019, and I’ve got another new job - my first with an actual software engineer title. We now jump to present tense, as this is my current job as of this writing.

The tech stack at this role is Python on the backend. I’d hardly worked with Python prior to this role, so in my first month I watched some professional development videos to get up to speed on the language.

When it came time to choose an IDE, I originally settled with PyCharm. It was almost identical to IntelliJ with which I was already familiar, and most of my coworkers were also using PyCharm.

Over the next few months, a few catalyzing factors lead to me using Emacs exclusively, which we’ll go over in detail.

Community

While I’m the only person at my current role who uses Emacs, I started to meet others who did use it.

I started showing up a little more regularly to the Emacs NY Meetup, and chatting with other there.

I started watching more YouTube videos about Emacs topics, which were mostly recorded from previous sessions of the NY meetup which I had begun attending. This spurred my interest in some other topics, which I will discuss below, but mainly the videos helped instill that sense of community further.

I started listening to all the Emacs related podcasts that were available, getting a much better understanding of the ecosystem in the process. Emacs is a lot less intimidating when you understand to what names like helm, company and projectile pertain.

Lastly and most importantly, I discovered my friend Adrien is a pseudo-celebrity in the Emacs community. He’s distributed packages for managing Kubernetes, Habitica and Todoist from inside Emacs.

Org-Mode

I’m sure if the the population of new Emacs users from the past ~15 years was surveyed on what made them try Emacs, I’m sure Org-Mode would feature prominently as a reason.

Org-Mode is extremely feature rich and difficult to explain succinctly, but at a high level it is an Emacs major mode that is well suited to note taking, task tracking and outlining. Many users manage all aspects of their productive life via org-mode. One of the coolest aspects of org-mode is the agenda view, which will consolidate your TODOs and calendar events striped across multiple org files and present them in a daily/weekly view.

When I discovered org-mode, I was staggered across 3 different apps to manage my work to-do’s, personal to-do’s, list management, Dungeons and Dragons organization, etc. Org-mode was clearly the tool that I wanted and needed, and this pushed me heavily into the full-time Emacs camp.

As of this writing, I use org-mode primarily for note taking as well as managing personal project coding TODOs. I use an external todo app (Todoist) for all other things. Once I have time to spend on it, I can configure the package Adrien wrote to get some Emacs Todoist integration.

Experience

Honestly, I was just in a better position to dive into Emacs at this junction. I had gotten more experience wrangling configurations, reading documentation and writing code.

I don’t believe that you need to be a programmer (or otherwise highly technical) to use Emacs effectively. That being said, I believe that the experience I gathered in my professional career helped me develop a tinkerer’s passion. Having this passion fuels my need to endlessly tinker and tweak my Emacs setup, the results of which bring me a lot of joy.

let’s get technical: what packages were critical to using Emacs as the primary IDE?

For this section, I use the term “productivity” to refer to my ability to and the ease with which I am able to translate thought into code.

Before I was willing to commit to Emacs as my primary IDE, I had to ensure that I could at least be close to as productive as I was in my existing tools.

The first tool that I really needed to do my job in Emacs was a python mode. I settled on elpy, as this seemed a common choice. Elpy offered the IDE-like experience I needed for Python development. It wasn’t quite as feature rich as PyCharm with regards to flexible code navigation and global refactoring (Note: JetBrains global refactoring is black magic), but it certainly helped me get up and running. Elpy also helped me to learn more about the ecosystem - I learned about packages like company and flycheck.

Now I was up and running with a Python IDE. However, I was very clunky at navigating around Emacs and my project; I could not switch buffers effectively, and I would consistently find files by exact path (watching me do this was a nightmare, trust me). The next two packages that I really needed were Helm and Projectile.

Helm is an incremental search and selection narrowing framework, but it feels like a lot more than that. In the way that I use it, Helm is effectively a tool that, when searching, opens new buffers with results that are easily navigable.

Projectile is a tool that makes it easy to work with “projects”. In my context, a project is almost always a git repository. Projectile offers functions to quickly switch between registered projects, find files within a project, find text patterns within a project, etc.

At this point, I’m almost caught up to my original productivity, with the added benefit that I was having a lot of fun as well.

Out of curiosity, I swapped over from elpy to using lsp-mode. Once I got it configured, I found it to be snappier and got me closer to that “IDE” feeling with features like peeking into definitions of functions. I’m still at the time of this writing running into occasional issues with lsp-mode - it’s pretty bleeding edge at this point, especially if you’re using the pyls. Some of my issues will be resolved with my primary work codebase completes its python2 -> python3 migration, with the eventual dependency bump.

Another package that I started leveraging at this point was yasnippet. This is a legendary package - it’s a snippet creator, but it allows embedding arbitrary emacs-lisp code into your templates, so it becomes something much more powerful. I’ve still only scratched the surface here. I highly recommend this community library.

The package that has consistently had my coworkers ooh-ing and aah-ing is restclient. This makes making HTTP requests very smooth, and has allowed me to almost entirely offboard from Postman. Additionally, my friend Adrien is working on a package, walkman, to do HTTP requests in an org file. With a little more customization, one can get an even more Postman-like experience.

I still have a ways to go - I still don’t have great tools for refactoring, nor have I spent much time sharpening the knife of making my editing more efficient.

in summary

I hope that this was an interesting read for you, and that it maybe sparks an interest in using Emacs yourself - as well as being an efficient tool, it can be a fun hobby.

Please feel encouraged to reach out to me on any/all social platforms to chat about Emacs.

item.title: A Citizen's Guide to Cybersecurity
item.description:
TL;DR - You should use a password manager and two factor authentication.

What’s the haps, homeslice?

Nowadays, an individual’s online presence is dictated by many, many accounts. Each account has some primary identifier - typically a username, or more commonly an email address. Additionally, each account has its own password. We’ve been taught that these passwords must be secure - combinations of letters, number and symbols that would be difficult for someone to guess.

Relevant XKCD

It is not reasonable for most people to remember dozens to hundreds of unique passwords, especially if the passwords themselves are designed to be difficult to remember. As a result, passwords invevitably get re-used across accounts. Inherently, this isn’t an issue, right? Only you know the password.

Wrong.

TODO insert links to articles about breaches

You should assume that a malicious third party will get access to one or more of your online accounts from breaches.

If you’ve been using the same email for various services, as well as re-using the same password, then you have an issue. The attacker compromised one site, but got access to many of your accounts.

Diversifying the email address you use for each web account is not practical, especially given that each email account would have its own password. Thus, it’s much better to make sure every password you use is distinct.

How can we achieve this?

Diversifying your passwords

Cipher

One option is to create a cipher - a pattern to generate passwords on a per site basis.

As a case study, let’s create a Pokemon cipher to manage our passwords.

Our key will be the domain of the service - for example, “facebook.com”. Our password formula could be as follows:

password = 
    First pokemon whose name starts with first letter of domain 
    + number of letters in domain 
    + "!" if domain length is even, else "?" 
    + First pokemon whose name starts with last letter of domain

Using “facebook.com” as an example, the first pokemon whose name starts with F is “Fearow”, the domain has 8 letters in it, and the first pokemon whose name starts with “k” is “Kadabra”, so our password would be: Fearow8!Kadabra.

This approach would generally give us a unique password for each service, unless the domains have a common first letter, last letter and length.

The first problem of this approach is that everyone I’ve spoken to who uses a cipher to encode their passwords loves to talk about how they use a cipher to encode their passwords. This is tongue and cheek, but don’t share your security implementation details ;)

The real problem with this approach is that you’re introducing a pattern into your passwords.

Let’s say that a few of your passwords using this structure get compromised in large scale breaches. The compromised data that exists on the web looks like so:

facebook Fearow8!Kadabra
twitter Tentacool7?Rattata
instagram Ivysaur9?Metapod

Uh oh. All of a sudden, that cipher doesn’t seem so secure anymore - anybody who notices the pattern and determines your cipher formula has gained access to all of your passwords.

There are methods you could take you try to make your cipher more robust and “uncrackable”, but the bad news is that anything you design will inherently be crackable.

Well, what if you didn’t know any of your own passwords?

Password Manager

A password manager is a piece of software you can use to store all of your passwords.

ALARM BELLS, car tires screeching, screams in the distance

“Wait, you want me to put all of my passwords into one location? That seems wildly insecure. What happens if an attacker gets access to that?”

Hear me out, I promise that this is actually the most secure way you could manage your passwords as an average tech savvy citizen.

The Value

Using a password manager, you can generate random passwords for every account you create. When you visit those websites, rather than typing in the password manually, you can paste it directly from the password manager.

What a win, right? Our password diversification problem is solved - we have a unique password per service, so if any of those become compromised, you can sleep at night knowing that none of your other accounts have been compromised.

The downside of this approach is that additional mental load is added when trying to log onto a service, especially on mobile. When prompted for a password, you must switch to your manager, enter the password for that, traverse to the account password you need, copy it, switch back to the site, and paste it in. I hear you, that’s a pain, but it’s a worthy tradeoff.

Now, let’s talk about the elephant in the room: the one password to rule them all.

Master Password Security

Scroll back up and take a look at that xkcd comic again.

To summarize, this password should be something difficult for a computer to guess, but very easy for you to remember. It should be long and have some combination of different types of characters. Additionally, your master password should not be relateable to you at all. Please do not include your pet’s names in this password.

So, how do you generate a secure master password?

One way is to say a sentence that nobody has said before.

For example, I could say “The rainbow zombies are raiding Antarctica!”, and get a perfectly reasonable password of rainbow.zombies.raiding.Antarctica. For even more security, add in a few numbers or special characters that you can remember - something like rainbow.zombies?raiding.Antarctia!42.

Now, I’m no expert on entropy, but this is long and arbitrary enough that no brute force script would stumble into it.

But isn’t it risky to keep my vault in the cloud?

No, assuming you’re using any well respected and established password manager.

The place where you are storing your passwords is your password vault. Think of this as a locked box. When you first boot up your password manager and are prompted for your master password, all you have is a locked box. When you enter your master password, it unlocks the box and you are able to access all your passwords.

Your master password is the key to your vault. The company which has created the password manager is storing only your vault in the cloud. The password management company does not have access to your master password in any form. Only you have the key to open that box. So, if some very talented hackers did manage to get access to some vaults (it has happened in the past), they wouldn’t have access to your passwords, only a locked box.

If you’ve followed the guide above and created a sufficiently secure master password that can’t be guessed by social engineering, you have no real risk keeping your vault in the cloud.

Okay, you’ve sold me - now what password manager should I actually use?

There are plenty of good password managers on the market these days - you should balance price and useability.

The following are all fine options:

  • Lastpass
  • 1Password
  • Dashlane
  • Roboform
  • Keepass

Personally, I use Dashlane. It’s one of the more expensive options, but I enjoy their UI and emergency contact recovery features. They also have excellent sharing facilities.

Generally, I would suggest people go with Lastpass. It’s free, and excellent for what it is. Initially I was skeptical about it being free (“No such thing as a free lunch, what are they getting from me?"), but their business model appears to be based around their enterprise solution. Emphatic users of a free password manager are likely to suggest the enterprise offering to their businesses.

But wait, there’s more!

Let’s back up for a second. I said something really scary earlier, and it’s critical to this next section.

You should assume that a malicious third party will get access to one or more of your online accounts from breaches.

What?! It’s all well and good that when an account gets compromised it won’t potentially compromise my other accounts, but what about the accounts that we cannot let get compromised?

Accounts that would be destructive if compromised (e.g. online banking), or accounts that manage access to other accounts (email), must not be compromised.

Modern security is based on three aspects: something you know, something you have, and something you are.

Let’s hand wave the “something you are”, because that’s not really a commercially available option yet. Think biometric data, such as fingerprints. Imagine a future where only you are allowed to unlock your phone, and it knows it’s you by analyzing the DNA of the skin touching it. The future will be wild.

Something you know would be a password. This is what we must assume is not secure; because the “thing we know” must be stored elsewhere for web accounts, it is liable to be leaked. It’s interesting to breakdown a password as actually being “a thing I said I knew at the time of registration, and that future me will also know”.

That just leaves “something you have”. The combination of requiring something you know and something you have is referred to as two factor authentication.

So, let’s configure something you (and only you) have.

Two Factor Authentication

There are a number of ways to manage your two factor authentication, but the way I belive to be best is having the following:

  1. Physical security keys (e.g. Yubikey) - one you keep on your person at all times, and one that always stays plugged into your main computer.
  2. Mobile Authenticator app.
  3. Recovery keys, printed and stored in a fire safe vault.

You must have redundancy, if you do not you run the risk of getting locked out of accounts.

I’m not a fan of SMS two factor (which runs rampant), nor am I a fan of “get a prompt because you’re signed in elsewhere” style.

Accounts that should be secured with 2FA:

  • Accounts that have personal or financial information (e.g. online banking)
  • Accounts that manage other accounts (e.g. email accounts)

With 2FA set up, even if the bank you use has a breach that leaks your password, nobody will be able to get into your account unless they also have your security key or phone.

The Final Takeaway

The main takeaway here is that your username/password combinations for online services should not be trusted to remain secret. Your job is to ensure that when your account credentials are inevitably leaked online, it has little to no impact on you. You can achieve this via using a password manager to manage many distinct passwords, and securing all the important accounts with two-factor authentication.

Remember that this is all mainly to stop malicious third parties on the internet - all of this falls apart if someone gets physical access to your unlocked computer, or has a gun to your head.

Regardless, I hope this has been helpful! Please reach out to me on Twitter @wneville_ with any thoughts or criticisms you may have, always love a good chat about security.
